did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult Special Collections & Archives staff.
did.abstract: The Women's Studies Program was created in 1980 and became a major in 1989. In 2006, the program was renamed Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies.

The Women's Studies Program Collection documents some of the curricular and structural changes made in the history of the Women's Studies Program (now Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies). The materials include a 1977 paper by Sheila Tobias on the history and future of women's studies in general; a 1980 proposal for a Women's Studies Program; a list of core courses in the Women's Studies Program for the year 1981-1982; and an extensive 2002 report created by a student forum about the nature and direction of Women's Studies at Wesleyan.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Wesleyan University began offering classes about women's issues in the early 1970s, which was shortly after the first women were admitted to Wesleyan in 1968. Women's Studies was housed within the American Studies program for the duration of the 1970s. In 1980, a Women's Studies Program was formed, but it did not become an official major until 1989.
The name of the program was changed to Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies in 2006 to better reflect the changing nature of the curriculum.

did.unittitle: Envisioning a More Inclusive Women's Studies Program, by WMST 419, Fall 2002

scopecontent.p: In Fall 2002, a student forum (WMST 419) was offered in the Women's Studies Department. The full title of the forum was Envisioning an Inclusive Women's Studies Program: A Collective Forum to Create Change at Wesleyan. Under faculty advisor Gina Ulysse, the students enrolled in WMST 419 evaluated the Women's Studies Department and its curriculum and goals. Envisioning a More Inclusive Women's Studies Program is a spiral bound document that describes the forum's suggestions for revising the governance of the department and restructuring the Women's Studies introductory class.
